sense.name: the act of assigning a person to a non-elective job or position
sense.commentary: APPOINTMENT[+event][+social][+official][+assignment][+to_job][-elective] Note: refers to an agent's act of assigning someone to a job
sense.examples: The president's appointment of Smith to his personal staff was unexpected. Bob resented his boss's appointment of Mary as head of the task force.

sense.name: a prearranged meeting, date
sense.examples: I have an appointment at the hairdresser tomorrow at 2. The patient missed three appointments with his psychiatrist. This winery offers tastings by appointment only.

sense.name: furnishings or fixtures
sense.commentary: APPOINTMENT[+entity][+artifact][+furnishings] Note: usually occurs in the plural
sense.examples: Their stateroom had handsome brass and mahogany appointments. The monks rooms were very spartan in appointments. (few furnishings)

sense.name: the person who is assigned to a non-elective position
sense.commentary: APPOINTMENT[+entity][+person][+appointee] Note: refers to the person
sense.examples: Sally is the new appointment to the under-secretary of labor. It is customary for the president's appointments to resign when the president leaves office.

sense.name: a non-elective job or position
sense.commentary: APPOINTMENT[+relation][+role][+job][-elective] [+activity][+social][+livelihood][-elective] Note: refers to the job itself
sense.examples: John has taken up an appointment as head of communications. These appointments entail a lot of international travel with the chairman.

sense.name: legal authority transferred to one, granting the power to dispense property
sense.examples: Management of her trust was given by appointment to a private bank. They gave him power of appointment over the estate.
